docs.lead_paragraph: ON a quiet spring afternoon, the white building at 1181 North Sea Road looks like an oversize home, hardly uncommon in the Hamptons. There is a white picket fence, and tall trees that obscure the view from the road. The only noises come from rustling squirrels, chirping birds and passing cars. If only the Jet East nightclub were so serene on Saturday nights in July, Fred Hauquitz, who lives across the street, would be content. ''Either that or burned down, one of the two of them,'' said Mr. Hauquitz, 79, echoing the sentiments of other Hamptonites who live near nightclubs that throb to loud life on summer weekends.
docs.abstract: Article on law introduced by town supervisor Patrick Heaney that would allow Southampton, NY, to phase out nightclubs whose owners or managers repeatedly rebuff demands to address neighbors' concerns; law, still in draft form, would permit owners to recoup investments and convert nightclubs into restaurants, cafes or private homes; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Two pregnant court officers in Manhattan who did not want to take a gun requalifying exam for fear of harming their unborn children have lost the right to carry their weapons. The officers, Laura Steel, 38, and Dawn Tauber, 31, said they felt humiliated when they were forced to turn in their weapons on Thursday. State law requires court officers to take a yearly requalifying exam, which entails shooting 50 live rounds at a firing range. But the officers had hoped to reach a compromise with the state that would have limited their exposure to the noise and elevated levels of lead in the air at the range.

headline.main: Pregnant Guards Lose Their Guns In Test Dispute

docs.abstract: Pregnant court officers Laura Steel and Dawn Tauber are forced to turn in their guns after refusing to take mandatory annual shooting exam that would have placed them in noisy atmosphere with elevated lead levels (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The movies selected for the New York African Film Festival, which opens tomorrow at the Walter Reade Theater, are centered mostly on the concept of home. It is a theme highlighted in the work of the director Abderrahmane Sissako, the recipient of a mini-retrospective during the six-day festival. For Mr. Sissako, who is from Mali, home is something so deeply wired into the nervous system that it informs every decision: it is part of a person's genetic makeup. His blissfully absorbing ''Waiting for Happiness,'' which had too brief a run at last fall's New York Film Festival, will be shown each day of the festival.

headline.main: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Film; Where Home Is Encoded in the Genes

docs.abstract: Elvis Mitchell Critic's Choice review of work of Mali director Abderrahmane Sissako, whose movies are being shown as part of New York African Film Festival; photo of scene from Waiting for Happiness (S)
